stance_1: Everyone in my family is a meat eater
justification: The interviewee directly connects their own meat-eating with the habits of everyone in the family.

stance_1: Everyone in my family is a meat eater
stance_2: I grew up with fresh meat as the norm
justification: The interviewee states that family and community norms of farm life directly supported meat-eating.

stance_1: I buy more chicken because it is cheaper
justification: Buying more chicken is a way the interviewee adapts their home meat-eating habits.

stance_1: I enjoy the taste of meat
justification: The interviewee explicitly states enjoyment of taste as a motivation for eating meat at home.

stance_1: I enjoy the taste of meat
stance_2: I try to get more protein
justification: Both taste and protein are given as motivations for choosing to eat meat.

stance_1: I try to buy grass-fed, locally sourced meat
stance_2: I believe animals are treated more ethically in local sourcing
justification: The interviewee directly links the purchase of local, grass-fed meat with ethical treatment of animals.

stance_1: I try to buy grass-fed, locally sourced meat
justification: The interviewee describes buying local, grass-fed meat as part of their home meat-eating behavior.

stance_1: I try to get more protein
justification: Increasing protein is directly cited as a reason for eating meat at home.

stance_1: I grew up with fresh meat as the norm
stance_2: Everyone in my family is a meat eater
justification: Family meat-eating is directly linked to the norm of fresh meat growing up.
